author: farnamst
body:
PE means nothing, not trying to trigger people but it’s nothing more than a ratio.

Companies that earn high rates of return on low levels of capital investment always have high P/E ratios. Adobe needs about 0.40/sh capital investment to generate about 5.50/sh in earnings. The reason their P/E ratios run high is because of the efficiency of their earnings.

Compare that to Caterpillar, capital investments of 3.50/Sh to earn about 7-10/sh.

One company needs 1/10th earning power to grow the business and earn 20% roic and the other needs 1/3rd earning power to just maintain the business and generate 10% roic (not bad for their business but not as good as an asset light business like adobe).

That said, Adobe is probably a 120b company right now selling for 160b. A far cry from 8/2002 when it was worth about 44b selling for 10b growing the top line at a +10% clip. That discount to fair value is what drove to future high rates of return + savvy management in significantly growing the intrinsic value of the business. Good luck, forget PE and ignore adobe unless you think they can grow fcf to 12.5b annually from the current 3.8b. Enjoy.

author: MrOaiki
body: There is ton of software competing with Adobe. On the film editing side, there’s Final Cut Pro for quick media editing and there’s Avid for films and TV. For Audition, there’s Pro Tools that is pretty much the goto program for professional sound editing. As for Photoshop, that’s where Adobe is dominant for pros and semi-pros. But even when it comes to the latter, they have competition from phone app creators and easy to use “quick-fix filter apps”. Adobe has tried to go into that space with Photoshop Express but they’ve failed. So Adobe is a player among many, where they’re only dominant in still image processing.

author: kill0kong
body:
Thanks for the comment. Curious. What makes you say RDFN will be out of business?
My RDFN avg is $16 and is up pretty good from that point. I think it is better positioned in real estate market than other technology focussed companies like Zillow in the space. Its focus on tech and investments in expanding platform capabilities is amazing. IMO it is a slow but sure winner in real estate brokerage space.
My GWRE average is $79. GWRE is a monopoly in end to end cloud based solutions for large insurance companies. Insurance companies have just started investing in technology/ digital transformation for their processes and have a long way to go. GWRE is coupling its platform capabilities with AI/ML which allows for better CRM, risk management and pricing. I know few consultant friends who are making a killing in implementing this for their customers. The management is awesome as it is led by a former McKinsey partner who had worked in this space for 15 yrs or so.
Will take your word and buy more ADBE :)

author: Meymo
body:
Adobe. 

They’ve moved to a SaaS model and the majority of Fortune 500 enterprises are subscribed to them. They have a huge moat and are the undisputed leader in professional digital editing tools. Yes, there are free products that “do similar things”, but those tools are not used by experts in the industry. In addition to the corporate world, all of your favorite movie studios rely on Adobe’s products.

author: doomrabbit
body: I'm a web designer by trade. Around 2002ish, the two big names in software for the graphics industry were Macromedia and Adobe. They were trading lawsuits like crazy, alternately claiming that one was copying the other's interface. Stock reporters were claiming Macromedia was going to get killed. I saw the Macromedia team coming up with unique solutions and rolling out constant updates to dodge the lawsuits. It was childish finger-pointing. Macromedia finally invented the modern slider/docked sidebar method that is popular today and the lawsuits stopped. Stock kept tanking, I started investing. Bounced back 2.5x once it blew over.  Should have stayed on board when Adobe bought them out to get the better solution they made, but never second guess taking a good profit.

author: Stockbaron
body:
Bilibili provides high-quality content and an immersive entertainment experience, and have built their platform based on the strong emotional connections of their users to their content and communities. They started as a content community inspired by ACG, and have evolved into a full-spectrum online entertainment world covering a wide array of genres and media formats, including videos, live broadcasting, and mobile games. They have a young and culturally aspirational user base willing to invest in a high-quality entertainment experience.

Bilibili uses an Adobe Flash or HTML5 player, which can be manually switched, to play user-submitted videos hosted by either itself or third-party sources, while featuring a real-time overlaying subtitle system for interactive playback experience.

author: NextTrillion
body:
Strong statement considering very, very few companies ever have more than 25% market share as the market matures, unless they have bought out most of their competition (AB InBev has an estimated 28% market share) or they offer a very unique product that can not be replicated easily (Boeing, Adobe, Visa, etc).

Throw in some limited licenses and state border restrictions, and you may have strong contenders for a while, but once the market matures and regulations are loosened up, 25% is far too difficult to maintain. TRUL has captured most of the FL market, but that will dwindle as a percentage. They’ll still see strong growth, but the competition will always find a way to undercut their market share. It’s just basic market fundamentals.

As the cannaguy mentioned, 3/21 (14%) for CL and 2/21 (9.5%), of cultivation. That’s about 24% and doesn’t factor in retail establishments or newer small craft growers that could take over a huge % of the market. There are a lot of assumptions, simplifications, etc. Aka *napkin math.*

Just because some companies have a head start doesn’t mean they will be able to easily maintain it. Especially in the CPG market.

author: UnknownParentage
body:
This is a core problem with SaaS for companies like Adobe. The guaranteed revenue stream reduces the pressure on the team to innovate, as well as the feedback loop between sales and release quality (previously, people might not pay for the upgrade if they didn't feel a CS6 was significantly better than CS5).

Without feedback, the temptation is to get lazy and say "we can't do any better".

author: ExiledinElysium
body:
It's coming from poor people. The overwhelming majority of earnings growth in large corporations right now is from their ability to squeeze more money out of their customers for the exact same thing, not because they're generating new real value in the economy. Microsoft and Adobe are good examples. They're leaders in a tech sector that's switched almost entirely from permanent-license software sales to a subscription model. It's just making customers pay more over time for the same thing. Same with nearly all gaming companies--the move to subscriptions and in-game microtransactions.

This is, of course, just my angry morning opinion based on very little real information.

author: 4pooling
body:
Great companies win in the end. It's simple. 

There are amazing companies that do pay a dividend and there are ones that don't (BRK.B, AMZN, FB, ADBE, INTU, NFLX, etc). 

Which is why simple market cap funds (which track both dividend paying and non-dividend paying stocks are so potent. 

Really difficult to beat the Market consistently over time.

GE aviation is struggling. It contributes to just 25% of corporate revenue. With 737 airplane production on hold both Europe and US are laying off skilled workers. Eric vowed to contribute to 5G and was a strong player sometime ago.  Nokia is a Buy from Hold, and cut Ericsson to Hold from Buy. Ericsson for 5G is facing expectations that may be too high. The companies benefit ultimately are not phone companies. [Rather the cell tower companies need to install a lot more transceivers.](https://www.landmarkdividend.com/how-will-the-5g-rollout-impact-cell-tower-lease-rates/) I doubt by the end of 2020 the 5G stocks which is a lot will show up on the income statements. you can look at the [complicity and vendors (table btm) involved.](https://www.tomsguide.com/us/5g-release-date,review-5063.html) If you can find a 5G mutual funds I will recommend. If you find one etf, mf please post here.

Good luck.

author: 4pooling
body:
No, that's not what makes sense for most investors. 

I remember first learning about investing and obsessing about dividends. Then I learned about total return, tax efficiency and Risk Management. 

Focus on total return (price appreciation + dividends). 

Maybe you're aware there are also highly valuable stocks that don't pay a dividend. To name a few: FB, AMZN, ADBE, INTU, BRK.B, NFLX, etc. The S&P 500 includes both dividend payers and non-dividend payers. 

If you're insistent on dividends, there are several tax efficient dividend growth funds (for a taxable account) that closely track the Market (S&P 500). An example would be VIG (VDADX is the mutual fund equivalent) and NOBL.

author: wilfredian
body:
Facebook, Adobe, IAC (parent of Match)? All were obvious buys on Jan 1, 2019 and all outperformed the market. All three are major ownings of mine bought in late 2018 based on basic fundamental analysis (which includes growth and size of moat considerations!).

Of course fundamental investing can work. People sprout the fact that the majority fail to beat the indices as if it is proof that it fails. But the fact that the majority do worse than the average is an *absolutely trivial statement* with no worth. Almost any skill at all will have a distribution of results like that.

author: 4pooling
body:
I notice he doesn't go into detail of his simple money weighted returns and only focuses on his dividend income. 

In his taxable account, he has an asset allocation of 80/20 stocks/bonds. 

20% of his pie is allocated towards REITs which the dividends are taxed at his high income tax rate (he's a software developer). Therefore the other 60% of his stock dividends are taxed at the 15% qualified rate. 

He's mentioned he doesn't have a 401k which would protect his assets from taxation. He's most likely above the 22% tax rate and is now earning even more income thru YouTube ads. 

You may outperform his pie by letting professional portfolio managers track a dividend growth index. Some funds that have done extremely well in this bull market include VIG, VDIGX, NOBL, etc. 

Besides all that, in 2019, the S&P 500 which includes non dividend stocks like GOOG, AMZN, FB, INTU, ADBE, BRK.B gained 30%. It outperformed all of the funds listed above. 

You would have to compare 80% S&P 500, 20% bonds to his 80/20 portfolio of stock picks.
